item.title: [AAPL] Intel Extends Comeback as Investors Bet on Foundry Growth
item.description: After an 84% rally in 2025, the shares are near their highest level in two years, recovering from a 60% drop in 2024 when Intel appeared to be falling behind its rivals who were capitalizing on the AI boom. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs back from the dead,‚Äù said Kim Forrest, chief investment officer at Bokeh Capital Partners and a long-time Intel shareholder. A range of catalysts are driving the optimism: an improving financial outlook, new confidence from Wall Street as seen in recent analyst upgrades, speculation about new foundry customers, and even enthusiasm around the company‚Äôs potential to be a winner in President Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmerica First‚Äù campaign.

item.title: [INTC] Tech rally, US-Taiwan chip deal, power grid auction: 3 Things
item.description: US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are perked up in Friday's premarket as the tech sector and bank stocks are looking to rally. Chip stocks are roaring to life this morning after the US struck a trade deal with Taiwan, which includes Taiwanese tech companies investing a total of $250 billion into US semiconductor manufacturing. Lastly, the Trump administration is teaming up with governors to hold an emergency power auction to resolve the surging power costs expected from Big Tech's AI data centers. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more&nbsp;Morning Brief.

item.title: [INTC] TSMC Seeks Narrower Tech Gap in US, Taiwan Fabs
item.description: (Updates video to add Huang's comment that TSMC can consider collaborations on advanced packaging if it makes sense for customers and the wafer business; updates video description with additional comments.) Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chief Financial Officer Wendell Huang said the company will try to accelerate the transfer of its advanced chipmaking expertise to the US in the future, though it will still develop and maintain its most cutting-edge fabrication techniques at home. He said TSMC can consider collaborations on advanced packaging if it makes sense for customers and the company's wafer business. There have been no discussions about potential investments in Intel Corp., Huang said.

item.title: [AAPL] Trump Takes Credit For Intel's Surge But Hesitant To Raise Stake: 'I'll Invest More In Other Things'

(NASDAQ:NVDA), warning that the AI-driven chip boom is vulnerable to a sharp reversal.
